head.title: A Hydrogen Car in Your Future?

hedline.hl1: A Hydrogen Car in Your Future?

abstract.p: Eric Strong letter on Nicholas D Kristof's Feb 21 column cites fatal flaw in hydrogen-powered car technologym

block.p: I'm glad that Nicholas D. Kristof enjoyed his test drive of the $5 million hydrogen-powered car (''Our New Hydrogen Bomb,'' column, Feb. 21), but the technology has one fatal flaw that the Bush administration hopes that the public will miss.

I'm glad that Nicholas D. Kristof enjoyed his test drive of the $5 million hydrogen-powered car (''Our New Hydrogen Bomb,'' column, Feb. 21), but the technology has one fatal flaw that the Bush administration hopes that the public will miss.

In the United States, most hydrogen is produced by a method that also creates large amounts of carbon dioxide, a major greenhouse gas. Electrolysis, the only practical alternative to this method, relies on electricity derived from the burning of fossil fuels and nuclear power.

Until a serious commitment is made by our country to research and develop energy sources that are truly clean, futuristic cars powered by fuel cells will be no more environmentally sound than S.U.V.'s.
